Theme 3: Theoretical Perspectives on ICT Adoption

* Discusses two theoretical perspectives that explain the adoption of ICT innovations in agriculture: the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and the Innovation Diffusion Theory (IDT).
* The TAM suggests that individuals will adopt technology if they perceive it to be useful and easy to use.
* The IDT explains how innovations are adopted and diffused across a population, with factors such as relative advantage, compatibility, complexity, trialability, and observability influencing the adoption rate.
* Both theoretical perspectives have been used to explain the adoption of ICT innovations in agriculture, but the IDT has been more widely used due to its comprehensive approach and applicability to different contexts.

In summary, theme 3 discusses the theoretical frameworks that can be used to understand the adoption of ICT innovations in agriculture. The paper reviews two theories, the TAM and the IDT, and explains how they have been used to explain the adoption of technology in agriculture. The IDT has been more widely used, as it offers a comprehensive framework that can be applied to different contexts.
